title: Glutamatergic Dysfunction in Cognitive Aging: Riluzole in Mild Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: Cognitive aging is a major source of disability in an increasingly aging population. The paucity of effective treatments for cognitive aging disorders, and most importantly in Alzheimer's disease instigates a need for further research into novel therapeutic possibilities. Alzheimer's disease is the most common neurodegenerative disorder and its prevalence steeply increases. Glutamate-mediated excitotoxicity in neuropsychiatric disorders and in particular in Alzheimer's disease has been shown to cause significant cerebral damage. Early effective therapeutic intervention in Alzheimer's disease is critical in order to prevent or at least slow down neuropathological progression that will lead to widespread irreversible neuronal loss and significant cognitive dysfunction. Riluzole, a glutamate modulator agent, will be tested in mild Alzheimer's disease patients. Cognitive functional changes along with two established in vivo biomarkers, namely, Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy (MRS) and Fluorodeoxyglucose (18F) positron emission tomography (FDG-PET) will be evaluated.
description_detailed: A double-blinded, randomized, placebo-controlled study will be performed. Forty-two individuals with a diagnosis of mild Alzheimer's disease between 50-95 years old will complete the study. All forty-two individuals will have been on an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, which is FDA approved for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease, for at least 2 months prior to initiating the study, unless the medication was not previously tolerated. Twenty to twenty-two mild Alzheimer's disease patients will receive riluzole and another 20-22 will receive a placebo. All patients will have a neurological evaluation and neuropsychological tests performed to confirm that they meet criteria for probable Alzheimer's disease set out by the National Institute on Aging - Alzheimer's disease Association that recently revisited the NINCDS-ADRDA criteria along with FDG-PET biomarker consistent with Alzheimer's disease.

outcomeMeasures.title: Imaging Biomarkers FDG-PET SUVR in Regions of Interest
outcomeMeasures.description:
Change from baseline to 6 months in cerebral glucose metabolism measured with FDG PET in posterior cingulate cortex, hippocampus, precuneus, and medial temporal, lateral temporal, inferior parietal, and frontal lobes, referred to collectively as our pre-specified regions of interest.

Fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG)-positron emission tomography (PET) is an imaging procedure that measures glucose metabolism in the brain.It is a well-established Alzheimer's disease biomarker and predictor of disease progression. For each FDG PET scan, 5 mCi of fluorodeoxyglucose was administered followed by a 40 minute uptake period during which the participant was in a resting state. Images were acquired on a Siemens Biograph 64mCT scanner as a series of 4 frames of 5 minutes each. Using SPM12 (Wellcome Trust), motion correction was performed and frames averaged into a static image. Each 6 month scan was coregistered to the baseline FDG scan, which was co-registered to the participant's T1-weighted MRI scan.

outcomeMeasures.title: Imaging Biomarkers N-acetylaspartate (NAA) in Posterior Cingulate (PC) Measured Through 1H MRS
outcomeMeasures.description: N-acetylaspartate (NAA) is a neuronal viability marker measured through magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H MRS).In vivo brain levels of NAA, glutamate, tCr and other major metabolites were obtained using 1H MRS and a 2x2x2-cm3 Posterior Cingulate Cortex (PC) voxel of interest in approximately 6.5 minutes using the constant-time point-resolved spectroscopy (CT-PRESS) technique with TE 30 ms, 129 constant-time increments (t1) of 0.8ms, and TR 1500 ms and a receive-only 8-channel phased-array head coil.The levels of NAA and other metabolites were expressed semi-quantitatively as ratios of peak areas relative to that of the unsuppressed water signal (W) from the same voxels. For consistency with earlier MRS literature, levels of the same metabolites were also expressed as peak ratios relative to tCr area in the same voxel.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Some participants could not complete MRS study due to multiple reasons (eg could not tolerate lengthy exam, did not return to visit etc) or did complete it but quality control of the MRS spectra did not pass screening criteria for analysis.

outcomeMeasures.title: Glutamate Levels Measured Through 1H MRS
outcomeMeasures.description: In vivo measurement of glutamate with 1H magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) (a neuroimaging study) in posterior cingulate as a marker of target engagement at three and six months compared to baseline.In vivo brain levels of glutamate, tCr and other major metabolites were obtained using 1H MRS and a 2x2x2-cm3 Posterior Cingulate Cortex voxel of interest in approximately 6.5 minutes using the constant-time point-resolved spectroscopy (CT-PRESS) technique with TE 30 ms, 129 constant-time increments (t1) of 0.8ms, and TR 1500 ms and a receive-only 8-channel phased-array head coil.The levels of glutamate and other metabolites were expressed semi-quantitatively as ratios of peak areas relative to that of the unsuppressed water signal (W) from the same voxels. For consistency with earlier MRS literature, levels of the same metabolites were also expressed as peak ratios relative to tCr area in the same voxel.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Some participants could not complete MRS study due to multiple reasons (eg could not tolerate lengthy exam, did not return to visit etc) or did complete it but quality control of the MRS spectra did not pass screening criteria for analysis.

outcomeMeasures.title: Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale (ADAS) - Cognitive Subscale (ADAScog)
outcomeMeasures.description: The ADAS comprises two subscales, cognitive and non-cognitive. The Cognitive Subscale (ADAScog) is a psychometric instrument that includes 11 tasks and evaluates memory, attention, reasoning, language, orientation, and praxis, scored from 0 to 70. The full ADAS total is scored by summing the number of errors made on each task on a range from 0 to 150 so that higher scores indicate worse performance.The non-cognitive component was not used in this study. Obtained for correlation with neuroimaging biomarkers.

outcomeMeasures.title: Neuropsychiatry Inventory - NPI
outcomeMeasures.description:
NPI assesses psychopathology in participants with dementia and other neurologic disorders. Information is obtained from a caregiver familiar with the participant's behavior. Total score ranges from 0 to 144; Higher scores indicate greater disease severity.

Obtained for correlation with neuroimaging

outcomeMeasures.title: ADCS Activities of Daily Living
outcomeMeasures.description:
ADCS-ADL is a 23-item inventory developed as a Rater-administered questionnaire answered by the participant's caregiver. It measures performance of basic and instrumental activities of daily living by participants. The total score ranges from 0 to 78, with lower scores indicating greater disease severity.

Obtained for correlation with neuroimaging

seriousEvents.notes: Gastrointestinal hemorrhage with hospitalization and study article discontinuation
laboratory abnormalities (thrombocytopenia) with study article discontinuation
bradycardia and pacemaker placement with study article discontinuation

limitationsAndCaveats.description: 1.Sample size was relatively small, and results require replication in larger-sample studies. 2.lack of amyloid characterization. 3.MRS is unable to differentiate neurotransmitter or vesicular and metabolic pools of glutamate. Longitudinal MRS measurements can be subject to technical variability and head motion. 4. the study was not powered for neuropsychological outcome and clinical changes must be viewed only as directional/exploratory.

pointOfContact.title: Dr. Ana Pereira
pointOfContact.organization: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests riluzole, a small-molecule glutamate-modulating drug, to reduce glutamate-mediated excitotoxicity in mild Alzheimer’s disease with the aim of neuroprotection/disease modification rather than solely symptomatic cognitive enhancement. citeturn0search2turn0search6

Act: Key extracted details — intervention: riluzole (50 mg twice daily in published trials of AD); comparator: placebo; intended effect: reduce excitotoxicity and preserve neuronal function (disease-modifying/neuroprotective); biomarkers used: MRS and FDG-PET to assess target engagement and cerebral metabolism. citeturn0search0turn0search5

Reflect: Classification check — riluzole is a small-molecule pharmacologic agent (not a biologic) that targets a pathophysiologic mechanism implicated in AD (glutamatergic excitotoxicity). Therefore it fits the definition of a "disease-targeted small molecule." Alternative interpretations (e.g., calling it a general cognitive enhancer) are less accurate because the trial and drug mechanism focus on modulating disease pathology. citeturn0search7turn0search1

Web search results (selected sources used): (1) Riluzole clinical trial in mild AD showing preserved FDG-PET metabolism and MRS glutamate changes. citeturn0search0 (2) Reviews describing riluzole pharmacology: inhibits glutamate release, blocks persistent sodium currents and modulates NMDA/kainate effects — neuroprotective, antiglutamatergic small molecule. citeturn0search2turn0search6 (3) ALS Association summary confirming riluzole is an approved small-molecule glutamate-blocking drug (clinical use in ALS). citeturn0search1
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial tests riluzole, a small-molecule glutamate-modulating drug intended to reduce glutamate-mediated excitotoxicity and preserve neuronal function in mild AD. This mechanism acts on the glutamatergic neurotransmitter system (presynaptic reduction of glutamate release and modulation of ion currents/receptor function), which maps to the CADRO category for neurotransmitter systems/receptors. citeturn0search3turn0search2turn0search5

Act: Extracted details — drug: riluzole (small molecule); mechanism: decreases glutamate release, blocks persistent sodium currents and modulates NMDA-related glutamatergic transmission (pre- and postsynaptic effects); clinical evidence: a randomized mild-AD trial used 50 mg twice daily and assessed FDG‑PET and MRS showing preserved glucose metabolism and changes in glutamate measures (target engagement). These specifics support assigning a neurotransmitter/glutamate-target category. citeturn0search3turn0search2turn0search7

Reflect: Rationale check — although the trial emphasizes neuroprotection (which could suggest the Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection category), the direct pharmacologic target is modulation of the glutamatergic neurotransmitter system (release/receptor/ion channel effects). Therefore the most specific CADRO match is D) Neurotransmitter Receptors. If the intervention had targeted broader neuroprotective pathways without a clear neurotransmitter mechanism, M) would be appropriate, but here the primary mechanism is antiglutamatergic. citeturn0search2turn0search3

Web search results (selected sources used): (1) Riluzole randomized mild-AD trial reporting preserved FDG‑PET metabolism and MRS glutamate changes (trial details and 50 mg BID dosing). citeturn0search3 (2) Drug/pharmacology summaries describing riluzole as an antiglutamatergic small molecule that inhibits glutamate release, blocks persistent Na+ currents and modulates NMDA/kainate effects. citeturn0search2 (3) Mechanistic studies showing riluzole blocks persistent sodium currents and decreases glutamatergic transmission via pre- and postsynaptic mechanisms. citeturn0search5turn0search7 (4) ALS Association summary noting riluzole is approved for ALS and works by blocking glutamate release. citeturn0search1
